Human Variome Project Australian Node

Helping Australian diagnostic laboratories deliver better results for patients through secure data sharing.

Roadmap

Current Funding

The HVP Australian Node currently recieves fuding for further development work through the NeCTAR Project. This funding provides for four streams of work.

Portal Improvements

  • Genes
    • Statistics on number of variants
    • Links to related databases
    • Visualisation tools
  • Variant Instances
    • Raise a concern button
    • Capture & display SIFT score
  • Search
    • Search by range
    • Search by genomic position
    • Filter by pathogenicity
    • Sort by ... (pathogenicity, other fields)
    • Wildcard search of variants
    • Search by disease
    • See other variants from test/patient
    • Display last date uploaded
  • Lab Notifications
    • On pathogenicity consensus conflict

Future Development Plans

Standardising Variant Calls

There is a need to develop a consensus file format that can be used for the population of diagnostic grade variant databases with minimal human intervention. To further enable submissions to the HVPA Node, the next phase of development will focus on enabling rapid and simple submission of data generated during next-generation sequencing by uploading Variant Call Format (VCF) files to the HVPA Node.

Microattribution

The HVPA Node will also implement a system of providing microattribution to data submitters at either the laboratory or individual level. Microattribution is a concept that allows individual pieces of information, called assertions—in this case a variant and its pathogenicity—to be attributed to an individual, or team of individuals. Importantly, assertions that have been “microattributed” can be cited when included in journal articles or other databases and these citations can be tracked and measured, providing a means of incentive for data submission for researchers.
